name: steelpan
definition: Steelpan is a percussion musical instrument made from a steel drum.
description:
Steel pans originated in Trinidad and Tobago, after the French arrived with their slaves during the French Revolution.

The first steel pans were made from used oil drums but are now manufactured as an instrument all on their own to specific requirements.

The early metal pan musicians used a variety of tools to create the sound of metal music - including kitchen utensils and metal containers.

The pan is struck using a pair of straight sticks tipped with rubber. The size and type of rubber tip varies according to the class of pan being played.

Some musicians use four pansticks, holding two in each hand. Steel pan musicians are called pannists.

When the U.S. Navy arrived in the early 1940s they were introduced to the steel pan and its popularity around the world spread.

facts.name: The largest competition for steel bands is 'Panorama'
facts.value: The largest competition for steel bands is held during Carnival in Trinidad - called Panorama.

facts.name: Official national instrument in Trinidad and Tobago
facts.value: In 1992 the steel pan became the official national instrument in Trinidad and Tobago.

facts.name: Grown popularity beyond Caribbean countries
facts.value: Since the first steel pans and steel bands emerged the popularity of this music has grown. Japan, Sweden, Switzerland and many other non-Caribbean countries have steel bands featuring steel pan musicians.

facts.name: The World Steel Band Music Festival dates back to 1964
facts.value: The World Steel Band Music Festival is held in Trinidad since 1964.

facts.name: Have about a one and half range octave
facts.value: Steel pans only have about a one and half range octave which is not very much when compared to other instruments.

facts.name: Steel pan bottom has the shape of a bowl
facts.value: When making a steel pan the bottom of the oil drum is pounded into the shape of a bowl. Further shaping and tuning is done with hammers that create surfaces that resonate to make distinct sounds.

facts.name: Originally were played in steel bands
facts.value: Originally steel pan instruments were played in steel bands with instruments such as dustbins, biscuit tins, and soap boxes. Today steel bands include a variety of other instruments such as triangles, bongos, congas, vibraphones, other percussion instruments, and cow bells.

facts.name: First musician to wrap the sticks with rubber
facts.value: The first steel pan musician to wrap the sticks with rubber to soften the sound was Ellie Mannette. He also created the concave shape that still remains in the design today.

facts.name: Musicians who play the steel pan are referred to as pannists
facts.value: Musicians who play the steel pan are referred to as pannists.

facts.name: Bass steel pans are very large and difficult to move
facts.value: Bass steel pans are very large and difficult to move from place to place.

facts.name: Calypso music
facts.value: The most popular and well-known music played with the steel pan is Calypso music.

facts.name: The inventor of the double tenor pam was Bertie Marshall
facts.value: The inventor of the double tenor pam was Bertie Marshall. He also recognized that the sun had negative effects on the steel pan and started using canopies for protection during outdoor play.

facts.name: One of the first steel pan musicians to use a 55 gallon oil drum
facts.value: One of the first steel pan musicians to use a 55 gallon oil drum for creating the steel pan was Anthony Williams. He also invented the 'spider web pan' which is the popular choice for tenor pans.

facts.name: Trinidad steel bands competed with each other
facts.value: Early in the history of the steel pan in Trinidad steel bands competed with each other. Those who were members of steel bands were thought to be gangs members and street fighting was common. This resulted in steel bands being looked down upon.
